name: Libernova Plant
description: A next-generation nuclear power station with a capacity of 3.2 GW, providing electricity to over 5 million homes. Known for its advanced safety systems and efficiency.

name: Maplorion Station
description: A vast hydroelectric facility producing 2.5 GW, drawing power from strong river currents in the north. It plays a key role in Canada’s renewable energy grid.

name: Aztelon Energia
description: A 1.8 GW combined solar and natural gas plant, ensuring stable power even during cloudy days. It supports Mexico’s growing industrial regions.

name: Amazonara Complex
description: A massive 3.6 GW hydroelectric complex built along the Amazon River. It supplies much of northern Brazil with clean energy.

name: Pampyros Facility
description: A 1.4 GW wind and solar hybrid facility located in the Pampas. Its wide plains make it ideal for constant wind power.

name: Albryth Powerworks
description: A 2.1 GW nuclear and offshore wind hybrid plant. It symbolizes the UK’s transition to greener energy sources.

name: Lumivère Station
description: A state-of-the-art nuclear plant delivering 3.5 GW of stable electricity. It continues France’s tradition of relying heavily on nuclear power.

name: Rheindrax Plant
description: A 2.2 GW advanced natural gas station located by the Rhine. Designed to balance Germany’s solar and wind energy with reliable backup.

name: Vesunova Energia
description: A 1.6 GW geothermal and solar hybrid facility near volcanic zones. It harnesses both the sun and the Earth’s heat for sustainable power.

name: Iberasolix Plant
description: A 2.0 GW solar farm spread across vast sun-drenched fields. It’s one of the largest solar installations in Southern Europe.

name: Tulivento Station
description: A 1.3 GW wind power network, with iconic offshore turbines in the North Sea. It provides clean energy to Dutch cities.

name: Matterion Energie
description: A 1.9 GW hydro plant hidden among the Alps. Mountain reservoirs guarantee power during peak demand hours.

name: Alpenyra Plant
description: A 1.2 GW pumped-storage hydro facility. It works like a giant battery, storing energy by moving water up and down the mountains.

name: Vistara Station
description: A 2.3 GW coal-to-gas converted plant, modernized for cleaner emissions. It powers a significant part of central Poland.

name: Nordalis Energy
description: A 2.0 GW nuclear and hydro mix, ensuring stability even during long winters. It’s a cornerstone of Sweden’s low-carbon strategy.

name: Fjordyra Hydro
description: A 2.7 GW hydropower station built into dramatic fjords. Almost entirely emissions-free, it powers much of Norway’s west coast.

name: Aurivanta Energia
description: A 1.5 GW biomass and nuclear hybrid plant. It makes use of Finland’s vast forests alongside advanced reactors.

name: Skandora Windworks
description: A 1.8 GW offshore wind farm, stretching across the Baltic Sea. It’s Denmark’s flagship renewable project.

name: Bohemora Plant
description: A 2.0 GW nuclear facility, central to the Czech grid. It provides reliable base load power across the country.

name: Carpathora Station
description: A 1.6 GW hydro and nuclear hybrid plant located near the Carpathian Mountains. It balances renewable sources with steady nuclear output.

name: Anatryon Enerji
description: A 2.4 GW natural gas and solar mix. Positioned to serve both major cities and rural regions.

name: Volgryn Complex
description: A 4.0 GW hydro and nuclear mega-complex on the Volga River. One of the most powerful facilities in Eastern Europe.

name: Dniprovia Plant
description: A 2.8 GW hydroelectric station along the Dnipro River. It remains vital to Ukraine’s energy independence.

name: Deserion Sunworks
description: A 3.5 GW desert solar farm. It captures endless sunlight and feeds energy into growing cities.

name: Sahranix Station
description: A 2.2 GW hybrid of solar towers and natural gas. Designed for both day-time peak and night-time stability.

name: Gangetra Shakti Plant
description: A 3.1 GW coal, solar, and hydro mix. It powers millions while gradually shifting toward renewables.

name: Indaryon Energia
description: A 1.7 GW hydro station along the Indus River. Seasonal water flow makes it both powerful and unpredictable.

name: Longhua Nova
description: A colossal 5.0 GW nuclear and solar mega-plant. It stands as one of Asia’s largest energy hubs.

name: Fujinari Works
description: A 2.6 GW advanced nuclear station built with earthquake-resistant technology. Safety is its highest priority.

name: Hanryth Power
description: A 2.3 GW nuclear and offshore wind combination. It helps balance Korea’s heavy industrial demand.

name: Siamora Solar
description: A 1.5 GW solar park in central plains. Its endless sunlight provides clean energy year-round.

name: Mekoryn Plant
description: A 1.4 GW coal-to-gas converted plant. Modernized to reduce emissions while meeting rapid growth needs.

name: Nusaryon Station
description: A 2.0 GW geothermal complex on volcanic islands. It turns natural volcanic heat into stable electricity.

name: Australis Nova
description: A 2.5 GW solar and wind mix in the outback. It showcases Australia’s push toward renewable exports.

name: Ubunara Station
description: A 2.0 GW coal and solar hybrid facility. Built to modernize the grid while cutting carbon output.

name: Nilyth Complex
description: A 2.9 GW hydro station on the Nile. Its water flow has powered Egypt for generations.

name: Lagoryn Energia
description: A 1.8 GW natural gas facility. It stabilizes Nigeria’s power grid and supports urban growth.

name: Atlorya Solar
description: A 2.2 GW desert solar array. Famous for storing energy in molten salt, providing power even at night.

name: Persenyx Plant
description: A 2.6 GW nuclear plant, key to the country’s long-term energy strategy. It supplies steady base load power.

name: Baynara Station
description: A 1.7 GW geothermal plant, built on volcanic terrain. It provides reliable green energy to the archipelago.
